words.context_notes: Core mat word, extremely common in Russian internet culture, used as intensifier
Very common mat word, literally 'bitch', used for both genders in modern usage
Mat expression meaning disaster/end, very commonly used as exclamation
Strongest mat word, male genitalia, used in many compound expressions
Strong mat verb, sexual/violent connotations, basis for many expressions
Female genitalia, part of core mat vocabulary, used in many expressions
Common scatological term, widely used as general insult
Scatological term, less intense than mat words but still vulgar
Buttocks, common vulgar term, relatively mild compared to mat
Derogatory term for males, related to male genitalia slang
Literally goat, common insult implying stupidity or stubbornness
Strong derogatory term, implies moral corruption
Literally reptile, used as general insult
Derogatory term implying moral decay, literally carrion
Derogatory term about appearance, literally freak/monster
Mild insult for females, implies stupidity
Common mild insult, implies foolishness
Strong insult implying mental deficiency
Derogatory term with medical origins, now general insult
Strong sexual insult for women, implies promiscuity
Borrowed from Polish, sexual insult for women

category_system.description: Russian profanity categorization system based on traditional mat system and modern usage patterns
category_system.methodology: Based on linguistic research of Russian mat system and contemporary internet culture analysis

mat_system.name: Мат (Mat System)
mat_system.description: Traditional Russian profanity system with specific linguistic and cultural significance
mat_system.examples_note: Core mat words forming the foundation of Russian profanity

subcategories.primary_mat: The four core mat words and their direct derivatives

mat_system.cultural_context: Mat has special status in Russian culture, traditionally forbidden in public but widely used in informal settings

soviet_legacy.name: Soviet-era Profanity
soviet_legacy.description: Profanity terms that emerged during or relate to the Soviet period
soviet_legacy.examples_note: Political and ideological profanity from Soviet era
soviet_legacy.cultural_context: Many terms reflect resistance to or frustration with Soviet system

general.name: General Profanity
general.description: Common Russian swear words and mild expletives without specific targeting
general.examples_note: Basic profanity used for emphasis or frustration

scatological.name: Scatological Terms
scatological.description: References to bodily waste and related functions

subcategories.crude_comparisons: Comparing things to waste or filth

sexual.name: Sexual Content
sexual.description: Words related to sexual acts, anatomy, or sexually explicit content

derogatory.name: Derogatory Terms
derogatory.description: General insults and put-downs targeting individuals or groups

gender_specific.name: Gender-Specific Insults
gender_specific.description: Insults that specifically target based on gender

subcategories.gender_role_mockery: Mocking adherence to or deviation from gender roles
subcategories.sexual_behavior: Judging sexual behavior based on gender

anatomical.name: Anatomical References
anatomical.description: Crude or inappropriate references to body parts
anatomical.examples_note: Body parts used inappropriately or crudely

ethnic_regional.name: Ethnic and Regional Slurs
ethnic_regional.description: Derogatory terms targeting ethnic groups or regional identities
ethnic_regional.examples_note: Slurs against ethnic minorities and regional groups

religious.name: Religious Profanity
religious.description: Blasphemous or sacrilegious language targeting religious beliefs
religious.examples_note: Orthodox Christian and other religious profanity

borrowed_profanity.name: Borrowed Profanity
borrowed_profanity.description: Profanity borrowed from other languages and adapted to Russian
borrowed_profanity.examples_note: Foreign profanity adapted for Russian use

subcategories.english_borrowings: English profanity used in Russian context

internet_culture.name: Internet Culture Profanity
internet_culture.description: Profanity that emerged from or is primarily used in online contexts
internet_culture.examples_note: Memes, gaming, and social media profanity

1.description: Generally acceptable in informal settings but avoided in formal contexts
1.cultural_notes: May be used in casual conversation among friends

2.description: Inappropriate in most professional or public settings, causes mild offense
2.cultural_notes: Avoided in mixed company or formal situations

3.description: Highly offensive and inappropriate in most contexts, causes significant offense
3.cultural_notes: Limited to very informal settings among close acquaintances

4.description: Extremely offensive, taboo in public discourse, may cause social consequences
4.cultural_notes: Mat words and hate speech, strictly avoided in public

cultural_considerations.mat_system_importance: Mat occupies unique cultural position - simultaneously taboo and integral to informal communication
cultural_considerations.generational_differences: Younger generations more tolerant of profanity, especially in online contexts
cultural_considerations.regional_variations: Severity perception varies between urban/rural areas and different regions
cultural_considerations.gender_dynamics: Different social expectations for male vs female use of profanity
cultural_considerations.political_sensitivity: Some profanity carries political connotations requiring careful handling
cultural_considerations.script_considerations: Cyrillic vs Latin script usage affects perception and filtering complexity

context_system.description: Cultural and contextual usage patterns for Russian profanity
context_system.methodology: Sociolinguistic analysis of Russian profanity usage across different social contexts and historical periods

mat_system_traditional.name: Traditional Mat System
mat_system_traditional.description: Historical and cultural significance of Russian mat (мат)
key_characteristics: Integral to male bonding and informal communication
Carries both transgressive and expressive power
mat_system_traditional.historical_context: Mat predates Christianity in Russia, survived Soviet attempts at eradication, remains culturally significant

soviet_era.name: Soviet Period Adaptations
soviet_era.description: How profanity evolved during Soviet rule (1917-1991)
characteristics: Official suppression of mat in public

post_soviet_liberalization.name: Post-Soviet Era (1991-present)
current_status: Still largely taboo in formal settings

informal_male_groups.description: Traditional primary context for mat usage

mixed_gender_informal.description: Casual settings with both men and women

emotional_intensification.description: Mat used to intensify emotional expression
emotional_intensification.social_tolerance: Higher tolerance for reflexive emotional usage

creative_linguistic_play.context_dependency: Artistic merit can reduce offense level

group_membership_signaling.function: Demonstrates authentic membership in specific social groups

patterns: Public usage shows disrespect for authority

context_sensitivity: Same word, different severity by context

primary_sources.name: Russian National Corpus (Национальный корпус русского языка)
primary_sources.description: Comprehensive corpus of Russian language including colloquial and substandard texts

primary_sources.name: Gramota.ru Dictionary
primary_sources.description: Authoritative Russian language dictionary and reference

primary_sources.name: Mat Dictionary Research (Мокиенко В.М.)
primary_sources.description: Academic research on Russian mat system by Mokienko V.M.

primary_sources.name: Internet Language Monitoring
primary_sources.description: Analysis of contemporary Russian internet slang and profanity usage

academic_sources.name: Russian Mat: Linguistic and Cultural Analysis
academic_sources.description: Comprehensive linguistic analysis of Russian mat system

academic_sources.name: Obscene Language in Russian Internet Communication
academic_sources.description: Analysis of profanity evolution in digital communication

academic_sources.name: Sociolinguistic Aspects of Russian Profanity
academic_sources.description: Social stratification and usage patterns of Russian profanity

morphological_features.case_system: 6 cases (nominative, genitive, dative, accusative, instrumental, prepositional)
morphological_features.profanity_productivity: Mat words highly productive in word formation

phonological_notes: Palatalization affects perception and spelling variations
Consonant cluster simplification in casual speech

historical_background: Pre-Christian Slavic origins of mat system
Orthodox Christian influence on taboo reinforcement

mat_system_significance.cultural_function: Masculine bonding, emotional expression, transgression marker
mat_system_significance.social_taboo: Strictly forbidden in public discourse but integral to informal communication

religious_considerations.modern_secularization: Declining religious influence on language attitudes

regex_considerations: Homoglyph detection (а vs a, р vs p, о vs o)

compilation_methodology.approach: Multi-source compilation with linguistic and cultural validation

usage_notes.intended_use: Content moderation, profanity filtering, linguistic research
usage_notes.cultural_sensitivity: Requires understanding of Russian cultural context and mat system significance
ethical_considerations: Avoid over-censoring literary and academic content
Balance cultural sensitivity with free expression

severity_system.description: Russian profanity severity classification considering cultural and linguistic context
severity_system.methodology: Based on sociolinguistic research of Russian mat system and contemporary usage patterns
severity_system.cultural_context: Reflects traditional Russian attitudes toward mat and modern internet culture influence

1.name: Мягкий (Mild)
1.description: Мягкая ненормативная лексика, допустимая в неформальной обстановке
1.description_en: Mild profanity acceptable in informal settings
1.cultural_notes: These words are often used without serious intent to offend and may be acceptable even in semi-formal situations among familiar people

2.name: Умеренный (Moderate)
2.description: Грубая лексика, неприемлемая в большинстве публичных ситуаций
2.description_en: Coarse language inappropriate in most public situations
2.cultural_notes: Vulgar but not mat; causes moderate offense in mixed company

3.name: Сильный (Strong)
3.description: Сильная ненормативная лексика, включая некоторые производные от мата
3.description_en: Strong profanity including some mat derivatives
3.cultural_notes: Includes mat derivatives and strong insults; causes significant social offense

4.name: Жёсткий (Severe)
4.description: Мат и крайне оскорбительная лексика, табуированная в публичном дискурсе
4.description_en: Mat and extremely offensive language, taboo in public discourse
4.cultural_notes: Core mat words and hate speech; extremely taboo and may result in social consequences

mat_system_special_status.description: Mat words (хуй, пизда, ебать, блядь) have special cultural status
mat_system_special_status.severity_modifier: +1 in formal contexts, +0.5 in informal contexts
mat_system_special_status.notes: Mat is simultaneously integral to informal Russian communication and completely taboo in public

gender_considerations.description: Social expectations differ for male vs female speakers
gender_considerations.notes: Higher social stigma for women using strong profanity

generational_differences.description: Age affects both usage and perception of profanity
generational_differences.notes: Internet culture has normalized some previously stronger profanity among youth

script_presentation.description: Cyrillic vs Latin script affects perception
script_presentation.notes: Transliteration often seen as attempt to soften impact

political_context.description: Political situation affects acceptability of some terms
political_context.notes: Political profanity severity fluctuates with current events

mat_core_four.cultural_significance: These four words form the core of the Russian mat system
mat_core_four.linguistic_productivity: Form basis for hundreds of derivative expressions

ethnic_slurs.social_consequences: Can result in social ostracism or legal action

internet_euphemisms.notes: Abbreviated or modified forms used to bypass filters

usage_guidelines.content_filtering: Level 3+ should be filtered in public platforms
usage_guidelines.educational_materials: Only Level 1 acceptable, and only with pedagogical purpose

variation_system.description: Russian profanity variations including Cyrillic-Latin transliteration and obfuscation patterns
variation_system.methodology: Comprehensive analysis of Russian internet culture, gaming, and social media obfuscation techniques

patterns.qwerty_mapping: Keyboard layout confusion (Russian ЙЦУКЕН → English QWERTY)
patterns.visual_similarity: Visually similar Latin characters (а → a, р → p, о → o)

symbol_substitution.description: Character replacement with symbols or numbers

diminutive_augmentative.description: Russian grammatical forms that modify intensity

first_last_letters.description: Keep first and last letter, abbreviate middle

gaming_culture.context: Popularized through Counter-Strike and Dota communities

techniques.reverse_text: Reversed word order or character sequence

keyboard_layout_confusion.description: Accidental or intentional keyboard layout mixing
keyboard_layout_confusion.intentional_mixing: Using wrong layout to bypass filters

context_dependent: Same word different meaning based on context
